body:
Very nice contribution, thanks for adding such thorough tests and description!
Will merge this...

Code looks good, but it triggers a checkstyle violation: indentation includes a space.
Please have a look at the Travis CI logs...
Merging ...
I added a check to see if Wikipedia IRC port is available before running this test
I noticed your pull request seems to be hitting the same issue as mine, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-3741

Interesting. I still need to add some docs and squash my commits. I'll do that in the next day or two and retrigger the CI build- maybe the issue will have magically solved itself by then?

Good looking out btw, and thanks!
The changes look correct. If you could add a small test to verify that passing PARALLELISM_UNKNOWN doesn't modify the parallelism we're probably good to go.
and a rebase since github says there are conflicts ,)
Just a minor style comment. Good to merge otherwise. Thanks @vasia
Thanks. I'll fix the style and merge!

@rmetzger I hav efixed the issue you encountered. The problem was that the JM tries to discard all state belonging to pending checkpoints upon job failure, which effectively purged the write-ahead log. The simple fix is to not do anything in ExactlyOnceState#discardState.

Looks good. Failed test seems to be a Scala compiler issue, not related to this pull request.

Merging this...
Looks good, merging this...
Looks good, merging this...
Manually merged in 885d543be8a8c0d1acdffa0003e394347d5376ef
I need the classification loss function for work I am doing with L-BFGS. I would like to take it over and make the recommended changes since there has not been any activity on this for a while.

@StephanEwen 
It looks like did not merge into Flink Master?

Although Github marks the PR as closed, the change has been merged to the master branch. Because Stephan squashed the commits of the PR into a single commit and rebased the changes the PR is not shown as _committed_. You should find it in the [commit history of the master branch](https://github.com/apache/flink/commits/master).
Sure go ahead @skavulya.
Hi @twalthr, why we need a null literal? Please forgive me if this is a silly question...
It has been merged (in b188637b9016116728f0d16f94e213584b2abfd6), but as Fabian said, I squashed and rebased the commits, to GitHub did not recognize that it was merged.
@fhueske @StephanEwen Oh, I see. Thanks for the explanation.

Hi @danielblazevski, sorry for late reply. I checked your updated PR but your last commit (d6f90ce) seems wrong. The commit removes KNN.scala, QuadTree.scala, KNNITSuite.scala, and QuadTreeSuite.scala. Could you check again?

There are no silly questions ;-)
SQL fully integrates NULL in all its operators. So we should also allow it in our APIs as our runtime allows it anyway. You need it for e.g. `CASE b WHEN 1 THEN 11 WHEN 2 THEN 4 ELSE NULL END`
Thank you for the fix. I'll take a look at it soon.
I think you used the wrong JIRA issue ID.
Yes Ufuk, you're right! it is 3750...do I have to reissue a PR with the right branch name?

you should a) rename the PR and b) force-push your branch with the correct jira ID.

or just re-open, as you wish.

Hey @twalthr, thanks for the PR!
One comment is that we need to update the docs about the null literal and how to configure the null check. Second, I don't really understand the behavior when the null check is not set. We return some default values, but how were these decided?

I will update the docs. The default values are defined in `CodeGenUtils`.

```
  def primitiveDefaultValue(tpe: TypeInformation[_]): String = tpe match {
    case INT_TYPE_INFO => "-1"
    case LONG_TYPE_INFO => "-1"
    case SHORT_TYPE_INFO => "-1"
    case BYTE_TYPE_INFO => "-1"
    case FLOAT_TYPE_INFO => "-1.0f"
    case DOUBLE_TYPE_INFO => "-1.0d"
    case BOOLEAN_TYPE_INFO => "false"
    case STRING_TYPE_INFO => "\"\""
    case CHAR_TYPE_INFO => "'\\0'"
    case _ => "null"
  }
```

Shouldn't the program fail if we encounter `null` values in the non-null mode? Replacing `null` with default values sounds wrong to me and can easily produce wrong results without anybody noticing it.

I agree that it makes sense to disable null checks if there are none, but if there are some and the checks are disabled, the code should throw an exception in my opinion.
@fhueske yes we can also throw an expection if you like.
+1 to throwing an exception instead of returning a default value.

OK, sounds good. The exception can be implemented as a separate issue. I'll open a JIRA for that.
This PR looks good and can be merged, IMO.
Created FLINK-3759.
I have updated the documentation. I will update the EBNF grammar as part of FLINK-3086, because it seems to be out of sync anyway. I will assign FLINK-3086 to me, if thats ok?
Ah, thanks @yjshen for the explanation! :-)

Thanks for the massive refactoring @fhueske!
I looked over the changes and couldn't spot anything noteworthy. The only things that I don't like is the additional `TableEnvironment` creation even for simple table programs when using implicit conversions. Couldn't we just also provide a static `Batch/StreamTableEnvironment` if we call the parameterless `toTable` that just calls `(Stream)ExecutionEnvironment.getExecutionEnvironment()`?

@chiwanpark I added those files, forgot to run a `git add` statement before.  A couple of other files were added to the `flink-staging` directory, perhaps as a result of rebasing.  I see that in the master branch of Flink, there is no `flink-staging` directory, should I then just delete that directory?  Strange those files weren't moved/deleted during rebasing.

**Update:  I removed flink-staging from my repo, namely `git rm -r flink-staging`**  Had to then change some things in IntelliJ and some of the Travis builds are going through (Till mentioned once that it should be OK if some but not all builds go through)

@yjshen thanks for the explanation. You are right, the Table API has the same behavior.
I would merge this later together with #1881, if no objections...

I thought about that as well, but decided against an implicit conversion without TableEnvironment.

What might happen otherwise is that users try to join or union tables that have different implicitly created TableEnvironments or to register an implicitly converted table in a TableEnvironment. This does not work due to Calcite internals. I think it is better to make the Table/TableEnvironment relationship explicit and also easier to understand for users if an exception is thrown for the above reason.
If the Table API has the same behavior, why do the default values for nulls appear in the result of the tests?

I don't think we should handle `DECIMAL` as `double`. `DECIMAL` provides fixed precision in contrast to `double`. If we internally represent `DECIMAL` as `double` precision is not guaranteed. I think we need a special data type, serializers, and also custom math logic to handle `DECIMAL` correctly. Maybe Calcite offers some of that?

Because @yjshen's code example only applies if the null check is enabled. If not, there is no additional `isNull` field. So every operation needs a valid return value that is used in the following operations otherwise default.
Are there other systems support `not nullCheck` mode?
Yes, you are right. We need special data type etc. for that in the future. But until then we should treat it as double as long as we can represent it. I can create an issue for that.

Just a couple of typos from my side.
I really like it that we got rid of the `TranslationContext` and I'm in favor of the explicit relationship between Tables and TableEnvironment. +1 to merge!

> There is nothing more permanent than than a temporary solution ;-)

Please correct me, if I got something wrong.
This change adds support for `DECIMAL` literals. So we might have row fields of `DECIMAL` type and  might compute incorrect results until we add proper support for `DECIMAL`. 

It would be nice to support `DECIMAL` but I don't think it is more important than result correctness. Depending on the support Calcite (or other libraries) provide, adding proper `DECIMAL` support might be a complex task and might take some time.

Is there an urgent need to support `DECIMAL`?
@twalthr, OK got it. The default is used in both cases. +1 to merge and fix FLINK-3759 soon.

Thanks for the review @vasia.
I fixed the typos.
Thanks for having a look! I'll merge it...

Thanks for the fix, @skavulya!
Looks good to merge.
Manually merged

Thanks for the update @gallenvara. Aside from a few comments the PR looks good. No worries about the `GlobalProperties`. The internals of the optimizer are not straightforward ;-). 
Thanks for adding the tests for the distribution / key length!
Is it possible to get this merged into the 1.0.2 release?
I think it will go to 1.1.x release. Need some clean up to isolate the changes needed.
@fhueske PR updated.

> It's better to have a temporary solution than no solution ;-)

Calcite translates all decimal literals to `DECIMAL`. At the moment even `SELECT 11.2 FROM MyTable` does not work, although it could fit into `DOUBLE`. I thought it makes sense to support at least decimals of `DOUBLE` precision.
Merging...

Thanks for the refactoring @StephanEwen!
Will merge this.
will merge this.
Will merge this PR.

Thanks for the fix. 
Will merge this PR.
Changes look good to me. +1 for merging.
Thanks for your contribution @andrewpalumbo :-)
Thanks, will merge this PR to master and release-1.0 branches

Looks good to me!
Please merge once Travis gives green light...
As a followup, could we add some "Assume" statements in the tests that check whether the Java version is either Java 7 or Java 8u51+ ?

This PR addresses FLINK-3717. 
Please review!

If everything is ok, could somebody merge this?
It has been some time that there is no activity here.
Hi @fhueske, I hope I applied all your comments, so it would be nice if you could have a look at it once again.

@tillrohrmann @chiwanpark does the re-basing look OK now?  Some of the CI builds didn't go through, 2 passed, 2 failed and 1 timed out (it seems there is a 2hr max limit for the CI process).

**Update:  Made another commit to put the more updated knn docs in, and 4/5 builds passed and none timed out**
Thank you guys!
Thanks for the update @smarthi. Will merge this PR.

Hi @greghogan,
thank you for the PR. This is a big addition! Are all the changes related to the clustering coefficient JIRA? Could it maybe be split into smaller PRs in order to make reviewing easier?
For big changes like this, it usually a good idea to create a design document to show the high-level approach and functionality to be added and discuss it with the community. Do you think it would make sense to do this?
Thank you!

It's certainly nicer to review small PRs, but I also like to present the big picture and context in which the features will be used. What if I leave this here, break out the dependencies into new PRs, and then rebase this PR down if those features are accepted? I'm not quite sure what a design document would cover. There's not much sophisticated here as with SG or GSA.
Failed on one build @ error: scala.reflect.internal.MissingRequirementError: object scala.runtime in compiler mirror not found.

One build failed on error: scala.reflect.internal.MissingRequirementError: object scala.runtime in compiler mirror not found.

Another on some weird YARN stuff, which I didn't touch. Flakey builds?

Ideally, each PR should make a single change and reference a single JIRA issue. If you could break this into smaller changes, that'd be great. Otherwise, it would really help if you could give a more detailed description of changes and additions. Thanks!
Merging.

Thanks for the contribution, @samaitra ! 
PR looks good to merge.
Thank you @fhueske. Changes look good to me. +1 to merge.
there are a few formatting issues with missing spaces after if/braces.
Thanks for this PR! Apart from a minor comment, it looks good to merge.
+1 to what @vasia said.

@twalthr I see your point. Is it possible to support at least decimals of double precision without running into the risk of returning wrong results? If not, I don't think we should go for this temporary solution.
Looks good to me.
Merging ...
Thanks for reviewing @fhueske! I will merge this...
Merging.
Merging.
Merging.

Hi @dawidwys, thanks for the update and the extensive tests you added! 
I had a few minor comments and I am not sure about the tests that check the correctness of the range partitioning. Maybe I missed something, but it would be nice if you could check the `PartitionITCase` again. Thanks!
Yes the failing tests are most likely caused by the build infrastructure.
@StephanEwen Adding "Assume" statements is a good idea. We could limit them to the affected tests.
Any thoughts on this approach or go ahead and write docs/prepare to merge?
Thanks for the contribution! I had an inline comment. If that's fixed, this looks good.
